title: The Ledger and the Levee
tagline: In the churning heart of a nation, one man's memory holds the key to its fortune and its soul.
themes: The Illusion of Individual Agency in a System of Capital
Memory as Both a Personal Gift and a Commodity
The River as a Living, Indifferent Engine of Destiny
The Unseen Architecture of Power Built on Labor

chapters.title: Blood on the Bills of Lading

story: Write a scene where a minor dockworker observes Silas's perfect memory in action and realizes its potential valueâ€”or danger.
Draft a letter from Cornelius Leland to an unseen business partner, explaining his philosophy of 'physiological necessity' and his assessment of Silas Thorne.
Create a monologue for Elara Vance, reflecting on the difference between the practical knowledge of the chandlery and the abstract knowledge of the ledger.
Imagine a chapter from the perspective of the river itself, personified, watching the human drama on its banks with ancient indifference.
technical: Build an interactive 'River Ledger' that visualizes the flow of commodities (cotton, tobacco, machinery) through Silas's manifests, showing the network of plantations, buyers, and debts.
Create a text-based simulation where the user must manage dock operations, balancing cargo, labor, and time, with Silas's memory as a key upgradable stat.

council: Herman Melville (for the epic scale of industry as a force of nature)
Edith Wharton (for the intricate, unspoken architecture of social and economic power)
Upton Sinclair (for the visceral depiction of labor and systemic exploitation)
Toni Morrison (for the exploration of memory as a narrative and moral force)
